items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne, especially in the Free Prae Road area, as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (20/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mostly dry day. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated today, 20/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge due to prolonged rainfall over the last few days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  

This message will be updated by 18:00 this evening, 20/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wiske and tributaries to the River Swale

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, Winton Beck

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

The flood alert for the River Rye catchment remains in force as river levels are forecast to rise this morning (Sunday, 20/11/2022) around Ness and Nunnington, due to localised heavy rainfall earlier this morning. Flooding of land is still possible on land around the River Rye and its tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck and Spittle Beck, including at Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 20/11/2022, or earlier if the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Seven catchment remains in force as river levels are forecast to rise this morning (Sunday, 20/11/2022) around Sinnington and Normanby, due to localised heavy rainfall earlier this morning. Flooding remains possible on land around the River Seven and its tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck and Catter Beck, and to the East of Normanby. will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 20/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The high water levels in the Eastern Yar, continue to fall slowly. At Alverstone, the river level is decreasing by approximately 1cm per hour but is now below the level of flood risk to property. Likewise, the level at Sandown is decreasing at approximately 1cm per hour, however, Fort Holiday Park will continue to be affected through the next 24 hours. At Bembridge, channels will struggle to drain into the marsh while water levels remain high, especially over high tide. We are operating Bembridge sluice to manage the water level at Brading marshes. No rain is forecast for the remainder of Saturday (19/11/22), however the weather becomes unsettled from early Sunday morning (20/11/22). The current forecast suggests through Monday (21/11/22) into Tuesday morning (22/11/22) could see up to 40mm of rain. If realised, this would likely see flood warnings issued again for the upper and lower Eastern Yar catchment. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. Avoid walking or driving through flood water. This Flood Alert will be updated by 14:00 on Sunday 20/11/22.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Addlestone Bourne as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  TTherefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (20/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mostly dry day. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated today, 20/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding, although standing water and debris are likely to remain. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. Further periods of heavy rainfall are forecast from tomorrow, Sunday 20 November and throughout next week. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No further rainfall is forecast.
River levels are falling.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

The Western Rother is still high but is slowly falling. Minor flood impacts may continue to affect properties at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth and surrounding fields, rural roads and gardens in those locations. Between Liss and Midhurst, river levels have already fallen significantly from their peak with only minimal flood impacts expected there. Very little rainfall is forecast Saturday. River levels will remain higher than normal in Fittleworth until Sunday. Another 10-40mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please keep flood protection products installed in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. Please plan to avoid driving through roads prone to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen following recent heavy rainfall. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow, Monday 21 November, but we do not expect any further flooding at this time. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 
Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and taking action where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high but has now peaked and will slowly fall through Sunday (20/11/2022). Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. In Barnham, river levels are already significantly lower than their peak and falling. Any minor flood impacts in Barnham should reduce. Further rain is forecast in the area on Sunday (5-10mm), Monday (15-30mm) and Tuesday (5-20mm) which could cause more flood risk next week. Some roads, including Shripney Lane may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 21/11/2022.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Stour, River Lodden, River Shreen

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No further rainfall is forecast.
River levels are now returning to normal.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.92 m and is stable.

The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.13m and is rising by approximately 11mm 

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.

Pumping will begin at Episcopi pumping station when levels in the river allow.

Dry weather is forecast for today Thursday, 17/11/2022, with the risk of isolated showers.

The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain stable

We are closely monitoring the situation.   
  
This message will be updated at 12:00 on Friday, 18/11/2022.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message: River levels continue to rise on the Lower Dorset Stour due to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch. The forecast for the next 24 hours is for more settled conditions. River levels are rising at the Throop and Wimborne A31 gauge. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River Ouse levels remain high due to prolonged rainfall on 17/11/2022. Flooding remains possible on riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and Naburn, particularly around Naburn Lock. We have issued a flood warning for Naburn Lock. River levels in York peaked overnight on Friday evening at approximately 3.3m and are now falling slowly. The Ouse level at York Viking Recorder is currently just below 2.7m and whilst falling now, is forecast to rise later today towards a smaller second peak of approximately 3m on Monday morning (21/11/2022) in response to more recent rainfall. River levels have also peaked at Naburn but may rise to a smaller second peak Sunday evening or Monday morning (21/11/2022). Tidal levels are not currently of concern. Further rainfall is expected from today and river levels may fluctuate further, remaining high on Sunday and Monday. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 20/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse due to prolonged rainfall on Thursday, 17/11/2022. Flooding remains possible on riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith and South Esplanade. River levels in York peaked overnight on Friday evening at approximately 3.3m and are slowly falling. The current Ouse level at York Viking Recorder is just below 2.7m, and whilst falling now is forecast to rise later today towards a smaller second peak of approximately 3m on Monday morning (21/11/2022) in response to more recent rainfall. River levels will remain high today and Monday (21/11/2022) as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments. Further rainfall is then expected on Monday and levels may fluctuate further. We are closing riverside flood gates in York and the Foss Barrier is in operation managing flows on the River Foss. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 20/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This alert is no longer in force. River levels have fallen below levels of concern, and are forecast to continue falling over the weekend.

The risk of flooding in the Barlings Eau and Duckpool Catchment Area has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we will continue to monitor the situation.

The risk of flooding from the River Ancholme has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. Operational activity to manage water levels will continue. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we will continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River Ouse levels remain high due to persistent rainfall on 17/11/2022. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Ouse, including low lying land, particularly around properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Flooding is expected in these York riverside areas from Friday morning, 18/11/2022 and over the weekend. River levels in York peaked overnight on Friday evening at approximately 3.3m and are slowly falling. The current Ouse level at York Viking Recorder is just below 2.7m; whilst falling now is forecast to rise later today towards a smaller second peak of approximately 3m on Monday morning (21/11/2022) in response to recent rainfall. River levels will remain high today and Monday as the water makes its way down from upper catchments. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation and managing River Foss flows. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 20/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River Ouse levels remain high due to persistent rainfall on Thursday, 17/11/2022. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Ouse, including low-lying land, particularly around Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages. Flooding is expected in these riverside areas from Friday morning, 18/11/2022 and over the weekend. York river levels peaked overnight on Friday evening at approximately 3.3m, and at Naburn on Saturday morning. The current Ouse level at York Viking Recorder is just below 2.7m; whilst falling now is forecast to rise later today towards a smaller second peak of approximately 3m on Monday morning, 21/11/2022 in response to more recent rainfall. The Ouse at Naburn may also rise from this evening into Monday morning, 21/11/2022. River levels will remain high today and Monday as the water makes its way down from upper catchments. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 20/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 20/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels will remain high over the weekend. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this flood alert if necessary.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Thames in the Abingdon area but are beginning to fall. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing.   
The weather forecast for today is for dry spells with scattered showers. Further rainfall, some of which could be heavy, is forecast for Monday. River levels are falling slowly, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. 
This message will be updated this evening, 20/11/22, or as the situation changes.
